extracted_ttps.description: The attackers likely used social engineering or other tactics to trick users into executing the exploit, potentially through the use of the 'at', 'net', 'ping', 'reg', and 'sc' commands detected in the NLP analysis findings.
The exploit uses MMIO registers to interact with the GPU coprocessor, suggesting a potential vulnerability in the device's firmware or hardware.
The exploit uses a hardware feature to bypass the Page Protection Layer (PPL) for patching page table entries and protected data segments.
The attackers potentially used command-line tools like 'at', 'net', 'ping', 'reg', and 'sc' to execute commands and interact with the system.
The attackers used MMIO ranges to bypass hardware-based kernel memory protection, targeting unknown MMIO blocks of registers at specific addresses.
Exploits the JavaScriptCore debugging feature DollarVM ($vm) to gain the ability to manipulate JavaScriptCore’s memory from the script and execute native API functions
The attackers exploited a vulnerability in iOS 16.6, specifically targeting the MMIO ranges 0x206000000–0x206050000 and 0x206110000–0x206400000, to gain access to the device.
The exploit manipulates the page table entries and protected data segments to evade detection and achieve its goals.
Attackers may use command-line tools like at, net, ping, reg, and sc to execute malicious commands
The exploit uses the hardware feature to modify the system image, specifically the kernel code, to achieve its goals.
Exploitation of a vulnerability in Sony PlayStation Blu-ray drives to achieve code execution by using MMIO DMA registers accessible through SCSI commands
Attackers send a malicious iMessage attachment, which the application processes without showing any signs to the user
The firmware of the GPU coprocessor is unencrypted, which could allow an attacker to access sensitive information.
Launch the IMAgent process and inject a payload that clears the exploitation artefacts from the device
The pseudocode provided suggests the use of a scripting interpreter to execute commands on the device.
Attackers may discover and exploit unknown hardware features by analyzing firmware and reverse engineering
Exploits the remote code execution vulnerability CVE-2023-41990 in the undocumented, Apple-only ADJUST TrueType font instruction
Uses hardware memory-mapped I/O (MMIO) registers to bypass the Page Protection Layer (PPL)
Using commands to interact with the system, potentially for exploitation or execution of malicious code
JavaScript exploit is obfuscated to make it completely unreadable and to minimize its size
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

falsepositives: Legitimate JavaScript development or debugging activities

rules.title: Exploitation of iOS 16.6 Vulnerability
rules.description: Detects exploitation of a vulnerability in iOS 16.6, specifically targeting the MMIO ranges 0x206000000–0x206050000 and 0x206110000–0x206400000
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes accessing the MMIO ranges
False positives may occur if the MMIO ranges are accessed by legitimate system processes or other non-malicious activities

rules.title: Data Manipulation via Page Table Entries and Protected Data Segments
rules.description: Detects exploitation of page table entries and protected data segments to evade detection and achieve malicious goals, aligned with MITRE ATT&CK Defense Evasion tactic and T1574.012 - Hijack Execution Flow technique
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tools modifying page tables for performance optimization
Gaming applications using similar techniques for anti-cheat mechanisms

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detect Potential GPU Firmware Flashing Attempts
rules.description: Detects execution of GPU firmware flashing utilities or commands that contain firmware update flags, which may indicate attempts to access unencrypted GPU coprocessor firmware.

detection.condition: (suspicious_tool_nvflash or suspicious_tool_amdvbflash or suspicious_tool_nvidia_smi or suspicious_flag_flash or suspicious_flag_update) and not exclusion_trusted_path

falsepositives: Legitimate GPU driver or firmware updates performed by vendor‑signed installers located in standard Program Files directories.
System maintenance scripts that invoke nvidia-smi.exe with benign parameters.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Persistence via Boot or Logon Scripts Using IMAgent
rules.description: Detects creation of scheduled tasks via schtasks.exe involving IMAgent, which may indicate persistence through boot or logon initialization scripts.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of schtasks.exe with IMAgent, though uncommon

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Exploitation of Remote Services via ADJUST TrueType Font Instruction
rules.description: Detects exploitation of the remote code execution vulnerability CVE-2023-41990 in the undocumented Apple-only ADJUST TrueType font instruction
falsepositives: Legitimate font processing tasks
System maintenance tasks involving font updates

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Creation with JavaScript Execution
rules.description: Detects schtasks.exe creating tasks with malicious patterns combined with JavaScript execution, indicative of T1053.005 exploitation.

detection.condition: selection and (filter1 or filter2) and filter3

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts creating scheduled tasks via command line
Developer tools using JavaScript execution with task automation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Parent‑Child Process Relationship Indicative of Process Injection
rules.description: Detects potential process injection by identifying unexpected parent processes launching execution binaries with injection‑related command‑line arguments.

detection.condition: (suspicious_child or suspicious_child_alt) and unexpected_parent and (injection_api or injection_api_alt)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that launch PowerShell or Rundll32 from Explorer for automation.
Software deployment tools that use rundll32.exe to load DLLs.
Security products that may invoke CreateRemoteThread for legitimate purposes.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.Office.Interop.Excel; $excel = New-Object -ComObject Excel.Application; $excel.Visible = $true; $workbook = $excel.Workbooks.Add(); $sheet = $workbook.Sheets.Item(1); $sheet.Range("A1").Value = 'Exploitation Test'; $workbook.SaveAs("$env:TEMP\exploitation_test.xlsx"); $excel.Quit(); [System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal]::ReleaseComObject($excel) | Out-Null; Remove-Variable excel}"
attacks.description: Advanced: Utilizes PowerShell to create an Excel application instance, demonstrating potential exploitation through Office interoperability. This command requires Microsoft Office to be installed and does not directly escalate privileges but shows how an attacker might leverage Office for malicious purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an Excel file in the temp directory with the text 'Exploitation Test' in cell A1.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation command using JavaScriptCore to access and manipulate memory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to access and manipulate memory using the $vm feature, demonstrating basic exploitation capabilities without causing harm.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation command that demonstrates accessing a library function through the $vm feature
attacks.expected_behavior: The command not only accesses and manipulates memory but also demonstrates calling a library function, showcasing more advanced exploitation capabilities.

attacks.command: jsc -e "var vm = $vm; var lib = $vm.lib; var sys = $vm.sys;" -e "vm.map(0x1000, 0x1000, 0x7, 0x1b, -1, 0);" -e "lib.func('puts', 'Exploiting...');" -e "sys.call('execve', '/bin/sh', null, null);"
attacks.description: Advanced exploitation command that attempts to execute a system command through the $vm feature, simulating privilege escalation
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates a more complex exploitation scenario where it attempts to execute a system command, simulating the escalation of privileges. Due to its nature, this command is considered high risk and should be used with caution in a controlled environment.

attacks.description: Basic example: Appends a script to the user's bashrc file to simulate launching the IMAgent process at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will append a line to the user's bashrc file, which will execute and print 'IMAgent process started' when the user logs in.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=IMAgent Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/echo "IMAgent process started"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/imagent.service; sudo systemctl daemon-reload; sudo systemctl enable imagent.service'
attacks.description: Intermediate example: Creates a systemd service file for the IMAgent process, enabling it to start at boot time.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command creates a systemd service file, reloads the daemon, and enables the service to start at boot, simulating the IMAgent process startup.

attacks.command: sudo crontab -l | { cat; echo '@reboot /bin/echo "IMAgent process started"'; } | sudo crontab -
attacks.description: Advanced example: Modifies the root user's crontab to run a command at reboot, simulating the launch of the IMAgent process.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command appends a line to the root user's crontab, scheduling the execution of '/bin/echo "IMAgent process started"' at the next reboot.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr GetDC(IntPtr hWnd); [DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern int ReleaseDC(IntPtr hWnd, IntPtr hDC); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr CreateCompatibleBitmap(IntPtr hDC, int nWidth, int nHeight); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr CreateCompatibleDC(IntPtr hDC); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern bool DeleteDC(IntPtr hDC); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern bool DeleteObject(IntPtr hObject); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr SelectObject(IntPtr hDC, IntPtr hObject); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern int GetDeviceCaps(IntPtr hDC, int nIndex);' -Name Utils -Namespace WIA; $hwnd = [WIA.Utils]::GetDesktopWindow(); $hdc = [WIA.Utils]::GetDC($hwnd); $width = [WIA.Utils]::GetDeviceCaps($hdc, 1028); $height = [WIA.Utils]::GetDeviceCaps($hdc, 1078); $hbm = [WIA.Utils]::CreateCompatibleBitmap($hdc, $width, $height); $memdc = [WIA.Utils]::CreateCompatibleDC($hdc); $oldobj = [WIA.Utils]::SelectObject($memdc, $hbm); [WIA.Utils]::PrintWindow($hwnd, $memdc, 0); $path = '$env:TEMP\screenshot.png'; [System.Drawing.Bitmap]::FromHbitmap($hbm).Save($path); [WIA.Utils]::SelectObject($memdc, $oldobj); [WIA.Utils]::DeleteDC($memdc); [WIA.Utils]::DeleteObject($hbm); [WIA.Utils]::ReleaseDC($hwnd, $hdc);"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and Windows API, saving it to a temporary location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG image in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Use mspaint to capture the screen and save it to a temporary location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens mspaint and captures the clipboard content (if any) or allows the user to select a region to capture, saving it as a PNG image in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and System.Drawing, saving it to a temporary location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire virtual screen and saves it as a PNG image in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the current directory.

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen using the import command and save it as a PNG file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the current directory.

attacks.description: Capture a selected region of the screen and save it as a PNG file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to select a region of the screen, capture it, and save it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the current directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Example'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: This command creates a simple form using PowerShell, which could be used as part of a phishing attack to deceive users into entering sensitive information.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form titled 'Phishing Example' will appear on the screen.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing email > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt && start %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: This command creates a text file in the temporary directory with content that could be part of a phishing email and then opens it, simulating the action of a user receiving and opening a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file will be created and opened, displaying the text 'This is a phishing email'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$html = '<html><body>This is a phishing webpage.</body></html>'; $html | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\phishing_webpage.html'; Invoke-Item '%TEMP%\phishing_webpage.html'"
attacks.description: This command creates an HTML file that could be used in a phishing attack and then opens it in the default web browser, simulating the action of a user accessing a phishing webpage.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML file will be created and opened in the default web browser, displaying the text 'This is a phishing webpage'.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing email' > phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a local file named phishing_email.txt with content that could be used in a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_email.txt will be created in the current directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Download the content of a benign website (assuming internet access for this example) to simulate creating a phishing website.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_website.html will be created in the current directory with the content of the specified website.

attacks.command: bash -c 'echo "Phishing email content" | mail -s "Phishing Email" user@example.com'
attacks.description: Use the mail command to send an email that could be part of a phishing campaign. This requires a mail server setup and the mail command to be configured.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with the subject 'Phishing Email' and the body 'Phishing email content' will be sent to the specified email address if the mail command is properly configured.
